journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Dynamic modeling and robust control of an L-shaped microrobot based on fast trilayer polypyrrole-bending actuators

article-meta.aff: 1Research Center for Patient Safety, Mashhad University of Medical Sciences, Mashhad, Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Kashan, Kashan, Iran
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Mashhad, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Rozita Davoodi, Research Center for Patient Safety, Mashhad University of Medical Sciences, PO Box No. 9137913316, Mashhad, Iran. Email: davoodir@mums.ac.ir

abstract.p: In this article, analytical dynamic model derivation and robust position control of a microrobot based on fast trilayer polypyrrole-bending actuators employing quantitative feedback theory is presented. The conjugated polymer actuators based on polypyrrole can be employed to achieve microscale precision positioning, having a wide range of application including biomimetic robots and biomedical devices. There has been extensive research on modeling the electrochemical dynamics of polypyrrole bending actuators. However, the mechanical dynamics modeling of actuator remains to be unexplored. In this article, we first develop a proper mechanical dynamics model for the fast-conducting polymer actuators that matches well with the existing experimental results and then extend it to a microrobot. In the controlling part, the robust control quantitative feedback theory will be used to control the microrobot with variable tip loading. The numerical simulation results show that the quantitative feedback theory controller has consistent and robust-tracking performance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is an increasing request for new generation of actuators that can be used in devices such as artificial organs, microrobots, human-like robots, and medical applications. Up to now, lots of research studies have been performed on developing new actuators such as shape memory alloys, piezoelectric actuators, magnetostrictive actuators, contractile polymer actuators, and electrostatic actuators (Hollerbach et al., 1992; Hunter and Lafontaine, 1992). The main disadvantages of these actuators are low efficiency and high electrical power (Hunter and Lafontaine, 1992). The electroactive polymers (EAPs) seem to be among the best possible candidates for application in micromanipulation systems since they produce reasonable strain under low input voltage. The EAPs are relatively new class of materials that can be used as both sensor and actuator (Bar-Cohen, 2001). The conductive polymers (CP) and ionic metal–polymer composite (IPMC) are among the EAP materials that exhibit interesting sensing and actuating behaviors (Smela, 2003). There are many reports in the literature about potential application of the EAP in different robotic systems. Chen et al. (2010) reported the modeling of a robotic fish propelled by an IPMC actuator. Bar-Cohen et al. (1998) have presented several EAP-driven mechanisms that emulate human hand including a gripper, manipulator arm, and surface wiper. Jager et al. (2000) reviewed the current status of microactuators based on the EAP. They described microfabrication of these actuators plus the possible application of them in microsystems (Jager et al., 2000). We have proposed application of adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) in kinematic modeling of a soft microrobot based on conjugated polymer actuators (Amiri Moghadam and Moavenian, 2011). The main process that is responsible for volumetric change and the resulted actuation ability of the conjugated polymer actuators is Reduction/Oxidation (RedOx).Thus, based on different fabrication forms, different configuration of the actuators can be obtained, namely, linear extenders, bilayer benders, and trilayer benders (Kaneto et al., 1995; Santa et al., 1997; Smela et al., 1995). By applying a voltage to the actuator, the polypyrrole (PPy) layer on the anode side is oxidized, while that on the cathode side is reduced. The ions can transfer inside the conjugated polymer actuators based on two main mechanisms, namely, diffusion and drift (Madden, 2000). The trilayer PPy actuator, which could operate in both air and liquid environments, is a promising material for application in micromanipulation systems (John et al., 2008; Wu, 2006). But before they could be utilized in practical applications, it is essential to understand their dynamics. Especially in applying fast trilayer PPy actuator, the proper mechanical dynamics must be taken into account. Most of the available models in the literature of CP actuators focused on static operating conditions (Christophersen et al., 2006; Du et al., 2010; Santa et al., 1997); however, application of these materials in practical devices requires a dynamic modeling approach. Although Fang et al. (2008a) have proposed a dynamic model for trilayer polymer actuators, they have only used electrical admittance model of the actuator and ignored the mechanical dynamics; therefore, their model cannot predict the resonant frequencies or the effects of tip loading on the dynamic behavior of the actuator. The main contributions for modeling the mechanical dynamics of the fast trilayer PPy actuator are mainly limited to presenting and evaluating the experimental data (John, 2008; John et al., 2008; Madden et al., 2000; Wu, 2006). We have proposed two methods for modeling the actuation process inside the PPy actuators. The first modeling strategy is based on the application of external induced electrochemical moment (Amiri Moghadam, 2012; Amiri Moghadam and Torabi, 2011), and the second method utilizes the induced electrochemical strain in the constitutive equation of the actuator (Amiri Moghadam, 2012; Amiri Moghadam et al., 2011). In this article, a complete analytical dynamic model between the input voltage and output displacement of the fast trilayer PPy actuator will be developed based on the first modeling strategy by adding a proper electromechanical dynamics to the model of Fang et al. The assumed mode method (Kelly, 2007; Meirovitch, 1986) will be utilized for a vibration analysis of the actuator. The proposed modeling approaches will be validated based on the existing experimental data (John et al., 2008). This model can be used both to optimize the open-loop displacement of the actuator and to design proper controller, which will lead to the practical use of actuator in micro-/nanosystems. Consequently, the proposed actuator model will be extended for dynamic modeling of an L-shaped microrobot that consists of two identical PPy actuators. The robot has 2 degrees of freedom (DOFs) and can perform micromanipulation tasks such as microassembly. The kinematics and dynamics of the microrobot have been analyzed in detail and the obtained results are used for design of a robust controller based on the quantitative feedback theory (QFT). The free vibration of L-shaped structure has been studied by Bang (1996), Gurgoze (1998), and Morales (2009). We have adopted the method that was described by Morales (2009) in order to achieve a proper dynamic model for forced vibration of our microrobot. The application of PID controller for a PPy actuator based on a first-order model is presented in Madden (2003). The proportional- integral- derivative (PID) and adaptive control approaches based on a first-order empirical model are reported in Bowers (2004). In our previous works, we have used several controlling approaches to control the PPy actuators (Amiri Moghadam, 2010; Amiri Moghadam et al., 2010; Amiri Moghadam and Maarefdoust, 2012; Torabi and Amiri Moghadam, 2012; Torabi et al., 2009). In the present work, the robust control QFT will be employed for the control of our microrobot. The QFT controller will be used to achieve robust performance specifications over a specified region of plant uncertainty that is associated with the variable tip loading. We will utilize the QFT multi-input multi-output (MIMO) technique to satisfy the desired time domain specifications on the coupled dynamics of the microrobot. The numerical simulations will be employed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the QFT controller. Thus, the reminder of the article will be formed as follows:

list-item.p: First, the classical admittance model of the actuator will be briefly reviewed, and suitable mechanical dynamics of the actuator will be obtained based on the assumed mode method.
Second, the kinematic and dynamic model of the microrobot will be presented.
Finally, the robust controller QFT will be designed for tracking problem.

sec.title: Trilayer PPy actuator
sec.p: In this article, as an example of the conjugated polymer actuators, the trilayer PPy actuator will be considered. Figure 1 depicts the trilayer PPy actuator. As the name indicates, the trilayer PPy actuator consists of three layers. The middle layer is porous polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) that is used as a storage tank for the electrolyte, and on the both sides of it, there are polymer layers (PPy) (Fang, 2008a, 2008b; Wallace and Spinks, 2007).

caption.p: Three-layer PPy actuator.
PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride; PPy: polypyrrole.

sec.p: As it was mentioned before, the main process that is responsible for volumetric change of the conjugated polymer actuators is RedOx. Thus, in the trilayer bender, while the PPy layer on the anode side is oxidized and expands as a result, the PPy layer on the cathode side is reduced and contracts. Therefore, this difference in the volume will lead to the bending of the actuator.

sec.title: Electrochemomechanical modeling
sec.p: The electrochemomechanical model comprises two parts, namely, electrochemical model and electromechanical model.

sec.title: Electrochemical modeling
sec.p: The electrochemical model relates the input voltage and chemical RedOx reaction inside the PPy actuators. Figure 2 depicts the electrical admittance model. The detailed description of the equations governing the electrochemical model can be found in Fang (2008a, 2008b). It is shown that the admittance model (Y(s)=I(s)/V(s)) of a trilayer conjugated polymer is given by

caption.p: Description of diffusion and double-layer charging, and its equivalent electrical circuit.

sec.p: where the physical parameters of equation (1) are illustrated in Table 1.

caption.p: Definition of physical parameters.

sec.title: Electromechanical modeling
sec.p: The electromechanical model relates the input voltage and bending displacement of the PPy actuators. It was experimentally shown that the relation between the induced in-plane strain (ε) and the density of the transferred charges (ρ) is given as below(Madden, 2000; Otero and Sansinena, 1997)
where α is the strain-to-charge ratio. Thus, the induced stress is
where EPPy is Young’s modulus of PPy and ρ can be achieved in the Laplace domain as given below (Fang, 2008)

where W is the width of the PPy, hPPy is the thickness of the PPy, and L is the length of the PPy. The three-layer polymer actuators can bend based on the expansion of the top layer and contraction of the bottom layer. The induced stresses in expanded or contracted layers are assumed to be the same and in the opposite directions. The distribution of the induced stress is approximately constant along the thickness. Additionally, the application of gold layers on both sides of the PVDF layer diminishes the potential drop along the length of the actuator; thus, the actuation process is analogous with the pure bending within the actuator. Based on Figure 3, one can obtain the induced electrochemical bending moment as follows

caption.p: Stress distribution across the thickness of the trilayer polymer actuator.
PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride; PPy: polypyrrole.

sec.p: Thus, the relation between the input voltage V and the output bending moment Ta can be obtained as follows (Figure 4)

caption.p: Consideration of the actuation process an external moment.
PVDF: polyvinylidene fluoride; PPy: polypyrrole.

sec.p: In the next step, a proper mechanical dynamics model between the input moment and output displacement will be derived. Based on the assumed modes, method 1 can obtain the analytical model of the output displacement of the actuator as follows (Kelly, 2007; Meirovitch, 1986)

where y is the output displacement of the actuator, {φ(x)} is the vector of admissible functions that satisfy the geometric boundary conditions of the beam, {q(t)} is the vector of time-dependent generalized coordinates, x is the longitudinal axis, and t is the time. The kinetic energy of the polymer actuator can be derived as follows

Thus, in the matrix form, the motion equations are given as follows
Considering the damping effects, the equation (15) can be rewritten as follows

where [c] is the damping matrix. Consequently, equations (6) and (16) will construct a complete model between the input voltage to the actuator and its output displacement. The natural frequencies of the polymer actuator are obtained, based on the physical parameters in Table 2 (John et al., 2008) and equation (16). In order to validate our model, we compare the experimental results reported in John et al. (2008), with the obtained resonant frequencies using equation (16).

caption.p: Values of physical parameters (John et al., 2008).

sec.p: Table 3 shows that our proposed model could predict the resonant frequencies well. Figure 5 depicts the bode plot between the input voltage and the output displacement of the actuator.

caption.p: Experimental and obtained resonant frequencies.
Bode plot between the input voltage and the output displacement of the actuator.

sec.p: Figure 6 compares the magnitude bode plot of the experimental results reported in John et al. (2008) with our theoretical model, which indicates that our purposed model can predict the actuator behavior well.

caption.p: Bode plot between the input voltage and the output displacement of the actuator.

sec.title: Kinematic modeling
sec.p: In this section, we will present the kinematic model of our soft robot. According to Figure 7, our soft robot is constructed from two identical PPy actuators with physical parameters in Table 2. We attached one frame at each joint of the robot. It is obvious that the transformation matrix that defines the first frame relative to the second frame consists of a translation equal to the bending displacement (L1,y1(L1,t)) and a rotation equal to the bending angle (θ). Thus, we can define the transformation matrix that defines frame {2} relative to the frame {1} as follows

caption.p: Frame assignment for the microrobot.

sec.p: Assuming that the displacements are small, based on equation (17), one can derive the Cartesian position of the robot’s tip in the frame {1} as follows
or
Considering the fact that the actuation process is analogous with the pure bending within the actuator, we can obtain the bending angle (θ) as follows

Given the desired end effector position (xtip,ytip) in the world frame, the inverse kinematics problem is to obtain the associated bending displacements in the robot’s links (y1(L1,t),y2(L2,t)). Therefore, based on the equations (19) and (20), the inverse kinematic problem can be solved as follows
The results of the inverse kinematics problem for elliptical and square trajectories are presented in the “Application of QFT” section.

sec.title: Dynamic modeling
sec.p: In this section, we will develop the dynamic model of the robot. In the first step, we will derive the kinetic and potential energy of the robot, and next, the equations of the motion will be obtained based on Lagrange’s equations. These equations will be solved based on Rayleigh–Ritz–Meirovitch substructure synthesis method (RRMSSM) (Morales, 2009). Let us define the analytical solution of the bending displacements in each link as follows

where {φ1},{φ2} are the vectors of admissible functions, {q1},{q2} are the vectors of time-dependent generalized coordinates, x1,x2 are the longitudinal axis, and t is the time. The kinetic energy of the robot can be derived as follows

where (ρA)PVDFi and (ρA)PPyi are the products of density by the cross-sectional area of PVDF and PPy layers in each links, respectively, and mt is the tip mass. In equation (23), the first term refers to the kinetic energy of the first link, the second and third terms refer to the kinetic energy of the second link, and the last term refers to the kinetic energy of the tip mass.
By substituting equation (22) into equation (23), the kinetic energy can be written as follows

where [m] is the mass matrix of microrobot, and {q}=[{q1}T,{q2}T]T is the vector of time-dependent generalized coordinates of the microrobot. It must be noted that assuming the size of {q1} is n1 and size of {q2} is n2, the size of {q} will be n=n1+n2.
Similarly the potential energy of the robot can be defined as follows
Additionally, (EI)PVDFi and (EI)PPyi are the flexural rigidity of the PVDF and PPy layers in each link, respectively.
By substituting equation (22) into equation (25), the potential energy can be written as follows
where [k] is the stiffness matrix of the microrobot. The generalized forces (Qi(t)) can be obtained based on the method of the virtual work as follows
where {Q(t)}=[{Q1(t)}T,{Q2(t)}T]T and Tai(t) are the induced bending moment in each link that can be obtained based on equation (6), and
Based on Lagrange’s equations, in the matrix form, the motion equations are
Next, the modal analysis will be used to determine the solution of equation (29). One can obtain the natural frequencies of the microrobot by solving the eigenvalue problem as follows
where Λ is eigenvalue and {u} is the eigenvector of the microrobot that must be normalized with respect to the mass matrix as follows
Considering [u]=[{u}1,{u}2⋯{u}n], it can be easily shown that
Similar to the modeling approach that was used in the “Electrochemomechanical modeling” section, we use proportional damping model here as follows
where α and β are the constants. Let us define [C] as
Considering the damping effects, equation (29) can be rewritten as follows
Now, by defining
and multiplying both sides of equation (35) by [u]T, we have
where
By applying the Laplace operator to equation (37), we have
Considering that N¯i1=Ni1/Ta1 and N¯i2=Ni2/Ta2, after some manipulation we can obtain the dynamics of the robot as follows
where

As it is mentioned in Morales (2007), the selection of optimal admissible functions is very critical, because it can directly affect efficiency of RRMSSM. Moreover, we must use suitable quasi-comparison functions that are the proper linear combination of the admissible functions (Morales, 2007). Thus, based on the study by Morales (2009), the suitable eigenfunctions for the first link are linear combination of the fixed-free and fixed-fixed Euler–Bernoulli beam eigenfunctions, and for the second link fixed-free Euler–Bernoulli beam eigenfunctions will be the right choice. Figure 8 illustrates the first six quasi-comparison functions for the first link of the microrobot. Figure 9 shows the first four mode shapes of the microrobot.

caption.p: First six quasi-comparison functions for the first link of the microrobot.
First four mode shapes of the microrobot.

sec.p: Table 4 illustrates the convergence of the lowest three natural frequencies of the microrobot. According to this table, using a system with only 12 DOFs will lead to five-digit convergence of the first three natural frequencies of the microrobot; thus, as mentioned in Morales (2009), the application of the RRMSSM will lead to a simple and accurate model. We have also considered the effects of tip load variation and obtained the fundamental natural frequencies of the microrobot for carrying different loads. According to Table 5, the increase of the tip mass from 0 to 30 mg will decrease the fundamental natural frequency of the microrobot.

caption.p: Microrobot natural frequencies convergence.
Fundamental natural frequencies for variation of tip loading.

sec.title: Application of QFT
sec.p: There are many practical systems that have high uncertainty in open-loop transfer functions that makes it very difficult to have suitable stability margins and good performance in command following problems for the closed-loop system. Therefore, a single fixed controller in such systems is found among “robust controllers” family. The QFT is a robust feedback control system design technique initially introduced by Horowitz (1963), which allows direct design to closed-loop robust performance and stability specifications. Since then, this technique has been developed by him and others (Horowitz, 1963, 1992; Horowitz and Sidi, 1972, 1978; Houpis, 1995). In many techniques from “robust control” family such as H∞, the design is based on the magnitude of transfer function in frequency domain, but the QFT is not only concerned with the aforementioned subject but also able to take into account the phase information in the design process. The unique feature of QFT is that the performance specifications are expressed as bounds on frequency–response loop shapes in such a way that the satisfaction of these bounds implies a corresponding approximate closed-loop satisfaction of some time domain response bounds for given classes of inputs and for all uncertainty in a given compact set. Consider the feedback system shown in Figure 10. This system has 2-DOF structure (consider controller G(s) and prefilter F(s)). In this figure, P(s) is the uncertain plant belongs to a set P(s)∈{P(s,φ);φ∈Φ}, where φ is the vector of uncertain parameters, which takes the values in Φ. G(s) is the fixed structure feedback controller and F(s) is the prefilter, and D(s) is the disturbance at the plant output.

caption.p: Two-degree-of-freedom feedback system.

sec.p: QFT controller design method is briefly summarized as follows:

list-item.p: Step 1. Generation of plant templates prior to the QFT design (at a fixed frequency, the plant’s frequency–response set is called a template).
Step 2. Given the plant templates, the QFT converts closed-loop magnitude specifications into magnitude constraints on a nominal open-loop function (these are called QFT bounds).

Step 3. A nominal open-loop function is then designed to simultaneously satisfy its constraints as well as to achieve nominal closed-loop stability. In a 2-DOF design, a prefilter will be designed after the loop is closed (i.e. after the controller has been designed) (Amiri Moghadam et al., 2009; Yaniv, 1998).

sec.title: Application of QFT technique for MIMO systems
sec.p: The application of QFT to MIMO uncertain system still remains to be among the difficult controlling problems for engineers. The first application of QFT to MIMO systems was introduced by Horowitz (1991). After that, this technique has been extended by others (D’Azzo and Houpis, 1995; Horowitz, 1992; Houpis et al., 2005). In this article, we will use the MIMO technique that was introduced by Cheng et al. (1996). In this method, the basic idea is to convert the closed-loop transfer function to an off-diagonal matrix that can be described as follows

where tij(jω) denotes the relation between the jth input and the ith output, and βij(ω) is a positive real function of frequency ω. By means of fixed-point theorem, it is proved that we could substitute the MIMO system by its equivalent single input single output (SISO) systems provided that the suitable off-diagonal performance bounds are designed. In the study by Cheng et al. (1996), it is shown that in order to achieve an off-diagonal closed-loop transfer function, the below inequality must be held (consider Table 6).

caption.p: Off-diagonal performance bounds for the first link.

sec.p: where li is the open-loop transfer function, [1/qij(s)]=P(s)−1, σij(ω) is a small positive function that can bound the closed-loop transfer function, and ωh is the frequency behind which the feedback is not needed. Therefore, based on the above inequality and the iteration algorithm that is described in Cheng et al. (1996), one can design suitable off-diagonal performance bounds.

sec.title: QFT controller design
sec.p: The objective of this section is to design a robust controller for the microrobot with variable tip mass. Especially the tip mass will vary from 0 to 15 mg. The actuator physical parameters are presented in Table 2. According to Table 5, the worst case belongs to the tip load of 15 mg with the fundamental natural frequency of 2.5637 Hz. Suitable controller and prefilter are to be designed having the following properties:

list-item.p: First, the closed-loop system is stable: The robust margin is that the magnitude of closed-loop system for all considered uncertainty must be less than 1.15.
Second, it can track desired inputs: The robust-tracking specification based on suitable performance of the microrobot is overshoot (= 6%) and the settling time (= 0.8 s) for all plant uncertainty.

Third, it can illuminate the cross-coupling effects. This will be achieved by considering the following off-diagonal performance bounds (Cheng et al., 1996). Table 6 illustrates γ(ω) for the first link.

sec.p: We will describe the controller design procedure for the first link and similarly suitable controller can be designed for the second link.

At the first step, we must define the plant uncertainty (template), which is shown in Figure 11. Then having the robust performance bounds in the loop-shaping phase of design suitable controller and prefilter can be achieved. Figure 12 depicts the loop-shaping of the open-loop system for the first link. It can be observed that the nominal plant lies on its robust performance bounds that confirm the correctness of design. Thus, the designed controllers and prefilters are given as follows

caption.p: The boundary of the plant templates for the first link.
Loop shaping of open-loop system for the first link.

sec.title: Numerical simulation of design
sec.p: In order to validate our design, we use both time domain and frequency domain simulations. Figure 13 shows the time domain simulation for unit step responses. It can be seen that the QFT controller has robust performance over all ranges of the tip loading variation from 0 to 15 mg. Figure 14 gives the satisfaction of desired tracking specifications in the frequency domain.

caption.p: Unit step response for all considered uncertainties with acceptable output bounds for the first link.
QFT: quantitative feedback theory.
Closed-loop frequency–response with prefilter for the first link.

sec.p: To further analyze our controlling approach, we will simulate the disturbance rejection and tracking problems for our microrobot. Figure 15 illustrates the microrobot controlling block diagram.

caption.p: Microrobot controlling block diagram.
QFT: quantitative feedback theory.

sec.p: Figures 16 and 17 depict the response of the uncontrolled and QFT control system to an impulse torque disturbance that has been applied at a nonzero time. It is evident that the QFT controller has a suitable performance in disturbance rejection problem.

caption.p: Uncontrolled and QFT controller response to an impulse torque disturbance at the first link.
QFT: quantitative feedback theory.
Uncontrolled and QFT controller response to an impulse torque disturbance at the second link.
QFT: quantitative feedback theory.

sec.p: Two different paths have been chosen for tracking problem. Figure 18 shows the comparison of simulated and desired associated bending displacements for a square trajectory. Figure 19 depicts the tracking problem for a square trajectory. Figure 20 illustrates the end effector tracking error for a square trajectory. Figure 21 shows the required input voltage in the robot’s links for a square trajectory. Figure 22 shows the comparison of simulated and desired associated bending displacements for an elliptical trajectory. Figure 23 depicts the tracking problem for an elliptical trajectory. Figure 24 illustrates the end effector tracking error for an elliptical trajectory. Figure 25 shows the required input voltage in the robot’s links for an elliptical trajectory.

caption.p: Comparison of simulated and desired associated bending displacements for a square trajectory.
Tracking problem for a square trajectory.
End effector tracking error for a square trajectory.
Input voltage in the robot’s links for a square trajectory.
Comparison of simulated and desired associated bending displacements for an elliptical trajectory.
Tracking problem for an elliptical trajectory.
End effector tracking error for an elliptical trajectory.
Inputs voltage in the robot’s links for an elliptical trajectory.

sec.p: Based on the simulation results in tracking problem, it is evident that the QFT controller has consistent tracking performance.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the robust control QFT has been applied to control a microrobot with variable tip loading. In the modeling part, we have built a proper dynamic model for the fast-conducting polymer actuators that matches well with the existing experimental results. This model can be used both to optimize the open-loop displacement of the actuator and to design proper controller, which will lead to the practical use of actuator in micro-/nanosystems.

Subsequently, we have proposed kinematic and dynamic modeling of a microrobot based on the fast-conducting polymer actuators. A complete mathematical model based on RRMSSM has been developed between input voltage and output displacement of the microrobot. This model can be used to understand the dynamic characteristics of the robot and to design the advanced control system.

In the controlling part, the robust control QFT has been employed to achieve the desired time domain specifications on the tip position of our 2-DOF microrobot. Especially we have designed a controller that is robust against the parametric uncertainty in the system due to the variable tip loading. The QFT MIMO method has been utilized to illuminate the cross-coupling effects between the DOFs. The time domain simulation of the step response confirmed the robustness of the synthesized control system to variation of the tip mass. Moreover, the simulation of the design indicates that the microrobot has a good and consistent performance in both tracking and disturbance rejection problems.

Future work covers (a) investigating the effects of both geometric and material nonlinearity in the mechanical dynamics modeling, (b) employment of soft computing techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks plus evolutionary algorithms in the modeling and control of the PPy actuators, and (c) fabrication of microrobot systems based on the fast trilayer PPy bending actuators. The research is fortunately ahead of schedule and will be reported soon.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the referees for their valuable comments.
